articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: Analysis of World Population
articles.description: This website would give you an idea about the current world population and different indices based upon population.
articles.contents:
Population and Growth Rate
The relation between population of a country is depicted in the graph
below. Key finding from this graph is “Growth rate is inversely
proportional to income category.”



The key takeaways from this graph:
Most countries tend to have density around 100 to 500 per square
kilometer.
Countries with small population tend to have
very high population density.
Countries with large population tend to have
low population density.
Land area and Density
The relation between growth rate of a country and land area is
depicted in the graph below. Key finding from this graph is
“Density is inversely proportional to land area.”



The key takeaways from this graph:
Most countries tend to have density around 100 to 500 per square
kilometer.
Countries with small land area tend to have
very high population density.
Countries with large land area tend to have
low population density.
Income group and Growth rate
The relation between growth rate of a country and per capita income
is depicted in the graph below. Key finding from this graph is “Growth
rate is inversely proportional to per capita income.”









The key takeaways from this graph:
Most countries tend to have density around 100 to 500 per square
kilometer.
Countries with low income fall into the
developing category and have very high growth
rate.
Countries with high income fall into the
developed category and have very low growth
rate. Generally those countries have a growth rate lying
between -1% and 1%.
Developed
and Developing countries around the globe



Key takeaways from the graph are listed below:
Europe is dominated by developed countries, but
the rest are filled with developing countries.
Developing countries are more common that developed
countries.
South America, North America
and Africa is filled with mostly developing
countries.
Asia and Oceania is consists of
both developing and developed countries.
